content: I've heard this before. It's perfectly plausible. Black's angle is that these guys deliberately made bad loans because, as he puts it, they make lots of money in the short term, which was the whole intent. He also says that Paulson and Geithner are afraid to expose the fact (according to Black) that the banks got all this money because they are essentially insolvent. Revelation of this could cause a run on the banks, and Paulson and Geithner are trying to prevent that by withholding the facts. I agree one hundred percent with the Ponzi scheme analogy. Do you know what a credit default swap is? I know you understand what "bubbles" are and how the wealth created around them is artificial. Consider the implication of the bursting of several bubbles. The world has lost roughly 40% (so far) of its wealth. Think about all that has built around that 40%. It's gone, and never coming back. Now, what does that do for, say, jobs? And how the consumption based on those employed people is so vital to a consumer-based economy? This is why I understand the importance of this stimulus. It's bad, bad, bad in terms of deficits, but what else do we have left? If 40% of the private sector disappeared, how do we make up for that? The private sector sure can't do it.

content: quote: Originally posted by mcgreer: This is why I understand the importance of this stimulus. It's bad, bad, bad in terms of deficits, but what else do we have left? If 40% of the private sector disappeared, how do we make up for that? The private sector sure can't do it. The biggest problem that I have with that is the fact that the size that the economy was before this whole thing happened was artificial. It was bloated and as real as a $3 bill. The economy wants to contract to where it should naturally be. Stimulus only serves to keep this artificial, bloated economy. Stimulus only serves to stave off what the economy naturally want to do. Prices want to come down, but we aren't letting them (the banks would lose too much). When prices come down, wages will drop in direct relation (which isn't exactly a bad thing). When prices/wages come down and find equilibrium, the businesses will see demand for goods come back around and will thus need to hire more workers. Basically, it would be like a giant reset button on the whole economy. But, instead, we are trying to prop it up. I believe that by propping it up the only thing we will see is a long and grueling recession with the greater possibility of yet another crisis in it's wake. The thing is that real growth happens through innovation. The problem is that there has been no real innovation in any other market other than the tech/gadget market. Most of the growth we saw was based on things that had been here all along, we just found new ways to sell them. That is not a sustainable prospect.
